dialogues.speaker: TITLE SUPER
dialogues.text: Establish "STEDMAN FIELD" stadium. . The stands are PACKED with CHEERING FANS.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (voice-over) It was the all-state high school championship game. Bottom of the ninth, two out. PLAYERS in both dugouts are straining forward, SHOUTING. The PLAYERS on the field are in tight.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (voice-over) Fenwick was standing on third like it was getting set to explode under his feet. A 15 year-old, FENWICK, is anxiously poised on third base

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (voice-over) Fillmore High had us by a run, and it was a 3-1 count. The championship had come down to one batter: yours truly, Larry Burrows. LARRY BURROWS, 15 years of age, is at home plate waiting for the pitch. He spits, but it catches on his chin. He wipes it off and glances sheepishly at the catcher. The TEAM COACH, 35, is pacing in the dugout. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: Let’s go, Larry! Swing away, swing away! You can do it, Larry! Watch the infield, babe! There is an intense look of concentration on Larry’s face

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (voice-over) Haskins was throwing fastballs, because that was the only pitch he ever threw...so I was ready for the next one. The Pitcher, JERRY HASKINS, 16, winds up and throws. Larry swings: CRACK! A towering fly, going deep! Looks il it’s out of the park.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (voice-over) I swung perfect, got great wood, and hung it up there like it was heading for Mars. A ROAR from the crowd. But no! No! NO! It curves foul! By mere inches!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (voice-over) Then this gust of wind came up outa nowhere and nudged it foul. I swear to God, a gust of wind! Larry steps out of the batter’s box, frustrated. The scoreboard turns over: 3 and 2. Larry twists the bat in his hands, getting a good grip. The players in Larry’s dugout strain forward. CLIP METZLER, a curly-haired 15-year old nerd, and the resident "bench-warmer", leans out of the dugout, clappin

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Paste it, Lare! You can do it! c’mon, Lare! Have-an-eye, have-an-eye, have~an-eye, soo-wing, babe! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Larry steps back into the box, digs his sneakers into the dirt, sets the bat, and squints down at the pitcher, look tough.

dialogues.speaker: _ LARRY
dialogues.text: (voice-over) Why is it, when you do something terrific, nine times outa ten, you’re all alone? But when you screw up really big...the whole world is watching? The crowd is on its feet with anticipation. Haskins goes into his wind-up and throws. SLOW MOTION: the ball breaks RIGHT AT THE CAMERA, straigh and hard, coming closer and closer and closer. LARRY’S POV: As the ball hurtles towards him, a SWELL OF LIGHT SEEMS TO EMERGE FROM BEHIND IT. Larry blinks. - The ball closes in. Larry swings with all his might. The ball THUDS LIKE A THUNDERCLAP into the catcher’s mitt

dialogues.speaker: UMPIRE
dialogues.text: Steeee-rike Thur-eeee!!! Larry‘’s swing twists him around and he falls in the dirt Silence. The crowd stares in disappointment and horror. (MOS) The other team races out onto the field and hoists Haskins on their shoulders. Larry sits up, wiping dirt off his face and winces with t pain of failure and shame.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (voice-over) It was a perfect pitch. A pitch from God. Had my name all over it. And I missed. I really missed.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT. LARRY’S GARAGE ~ DAY (1990) - LARRY, now 35, is in his garage workshop, staring into space, lost in thought. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I still can’t get over it. I was sure I/d hit it. It was like the ball went right through the bat! (breaking his reverie) Ever have anything like that happen to you, Sammy? Re looks down at his MONGREL DOG, SAMMY, for an answer. T dog stares back attentively and BARKS.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Then you know what I mean. Larry goes back to gluing the tire on the immaculate mode of a ’54 Porsche Spyder he was working on. i

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Some memories just don’t want to go away I guess.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (9.s.7 echoing) You tipped that ball foul, Larry. Everybody saw it.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOCKER ROOM DAY, (1970)
dialogues.text: Larry is sitting in the deserted locker room, head down, staring at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: That ump was blind as a bat! So I got him some glasses. What d’ya think? He looks up. Clip Metzler, the "bench warmer", turns arou he’s wearing a pair of "slinky glasses". The “eyes" bob wildly back and forth. cLIP Aren’t they cool? Scared the crap out of my baby sister. Wanna try fem on? Clip takes the glasses off and holds them out to Larry.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Thanks Clipper, but I’d kinda like to be alone for awhile. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Sure, Lare. Whatever you say. Clip starts away, then turns back, still cheery.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Listen, I’1l call ya later. Well go to a movie or something. Maybe we'll see "Bonnie and Clyde" again. Okay? Larry nods. Clip leaves. Then Larry puts his head down. H winces, trying to hold back the tears. He HEARS the BANG of the door opening and he looks up to SEE the ballpark custodian, MR. RIPLEY come in. With him is his daughter, ELLEN, a pretty 16-year old. i Larry quickly tries te straighten up. MR. RIPLEY . Tough break, son. But don’t take it too hard. There’1l be other games. Remember, none of this’11 seem so important twenty years from now.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah...sure. The young girl hands Larry a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Here. Looks like you could use one of these.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks. I must have gotten something in my eye...all the dust and stuff... ELLEN . Yeah, there is alot of dust blowing around. Larry dabs his eyes then hands the handkerchief back.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: It’s okay, you can keep it. I got lots. My aunt sends me six dozen every Christmas. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Larry looks at the handkerchief TO SEE the initials EJR.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What’s E.J.R.?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Ellen Jane Ripley. What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Larry. Larry Joseph Burrows. They shake hands. She smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Larry.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (o.8.) ‘ Larry! eo INT. LARRY’S GARAGE DAY (1990) * Larry is looking at the handkerchief with the faded initi EIR.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: la , (o.s.} rry! He comes out of his reminiscence and turns to SEE: A WOMA standing in the doorway. It’s the adult version of the 16 year-old girl in the flashback.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I’ve been calling you for the last five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Sorry, I didn’t hear you. Ellen SEES the handkerchief in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (knowingly} Were you thinking about that silly baseball game again? He hides the handkerchief and holds up the model. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No, of course not. I was working on the ‘54 Porsche Spyder. See? She looks at him, disbelieving.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I was! Really! Ain’t it a beaut? dames Dean had one of these, you know. Course, his was much bigger...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: It was 20 years ago, Larry. I really don’t think anybody cares anymore.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I care. James Dean was a great actor. Remember that drunk scene in "Giant"...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: You know what I’m talking about. That baseball game’s in the past. It‘s not important, anymore.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Of course it isn’t. I know that. You’re the one who brought it up. Now what was it you wanted? Is breakfast ready?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: The contractor is here.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Great! I love the contractor. He places the Porsche on a shelf, beside an already-completed model of a ’34 Dusenberg.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: You/1l be firm with him this time, won’t you?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. "Firm" is my middle name. Larry "firm" Burrows they call me...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Well, you weren’t very firm the last time... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, who can remember back that far?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Just be firm with him. Ellen straightens the collar of his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Don‘t worry. "Firm" is my middle name. Larry "firm"...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (gently) Yeah, we heard... EXT. LARRY’S HOUSE DAY Establish the house: a partially-built modest home in a n subdivision. Larry comes out of the garage to meet GUZELMAN, a 300 lb Armenian, who munches a jelly donut and sips a coffee.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (good~naturedly) Hey, Mr. Guzelman! How’re you? Haven’t seen you the past six weeks. Thought you’d been captured by aliens.

dialogues.speaker: GUZELMAN
dialogues.text: “Got your message, what’sa problem?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well...it’s the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: GUZELMAN
dialogues.text: S’wrong with it? Larry looks down; he and Guzelman are standing in a very muddy driveway.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well, I tell you...it’s a little muddier than we thought it‘d be. You think maybe we could pave it?

dialogues.speaker: GUZELMAN
dialogues.text: Can‘t pave it ‘til all the mud’s gone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well...then all we have to do is get rid of the mud, right?

dialogues.speaker: GUZELMAN
dialogues.text: Don’t do mud. You need a mud guy for that.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: A mud guy? They have that?

dialogues.speaker: GUZELMAN
dialogues.text: Yup. Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well, now that you mention it, there are a few other things, like the plumbing and the wiring which don’t seem to wanna work.

dialogues.speaker: GUZELMAN
dialogues.text: Gonna need a check for that.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I thought I gave you a check last month. For a thousand bucks.

dialogues.speaker: GUZELMAN
dialogues.text: Need another one. Gotta hire a whole crew for a job like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if I give you another check, when do you think you’1ll get around to doing the work?

dialogues.speaker: GUZELMAN
dialogues.text: Soon.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I think that’s what you said last month, Mr. Guzelman and nothing happened.

dialogues.speaker: GUZELMAN
dialogues.text: Got busy on another job.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Listen, ya know, there’s gotta be plenty of other contractors around. If you’re too busy maybe I should...

dialogues.speaker: GUZELMAN
dialogues.text: Suit yourself. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Guzelman starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Alright, wait, wait. How much do you need this time?

dialogues.speaker: GUZELMAN
dialogues.text: Thousand.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Don’t you guys know any other number?

dialogues.speaker: GUZELMAN
dialogues.text: Two thousand. LARRY b Okay, okay, a thousand. v Larry quickly writes out a check.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Couldja at least gimme a rough estimate of what "soon" means. Is that next week? Next month? Sometime this century?

dialogues.speaker: GUZELMAN
dialogues.text: Soon. . Guzelman grabs the check and gets into his truck.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Sure ya won’t stay for breakfast? Guzelman backs his truck out of the driveway, splattering mud on Larry.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Try cashin’ that check, ya fat piece a crap. The truck slides to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: GUZELMAN
dialogues.text: Wuzzat?!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I said...see ya when ya get back! Larry smiles and waves as Guzelman pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ~11~ INT. LARRY‘S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM DAY Larry enters, sorting through the mail.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Ellen, did you forget to pay the electric again? We got a cut-off notice! He flips on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: It's okay. TV still works. The TV is tuned to a workout show: THREE BEAUTIFUL GIRLS thrust their pelvises toward the CAMERA. Larry pauses to watch, lust flashing in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: My God! How do they do that? (ealling out) Hey honey, can you do this thing with your leg where you put it behind your...? He turns to see Ellen enter carrying a bucket of water.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What? She points to a large yellow stain in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Sammy’s been decorating the room again. Sammy peeks in sheepishly from the other room. Ellen hands Larry the bucket and a sponge; then she exits Larry looks over at Sammy.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Sammy. Sammy backs out sheepishly. INT. LARRY’S HOUSE ~ KITCHEN DAY Ellen is frying eggs at the stove. Larry comes in, opening the mail. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sammy watches them back and forth as they talk, neither listening to the other.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I thought you said you were going to take Sammy to obedience school.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What’s with this Mastercard bill?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: You can’t just bring a dog in off the street and expect him to be housebroken, ya know. LARRY . What the hell is Neiman Marcus? And 4 why do we owe them 250 bucks? Ellen reaches down and slips Sammy a piece of bacon,

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (baby-talk) He‘s a mean old Larry for not teaching you to pee on the front lawn, isn’t he, Sammy? Yes he is.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What‘d you buy for two-fifty anyway, a mink coat or something?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Did you use the Lysol on the carpet? The smell never goes away if you don’t.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: The Lysol. What are you talking about? Larry and Ellen stare at one another.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOUSE DAY
dialogues.text: Larry gets into his car. Sammy jumps through the window i the passenger seat, excited and wagging his tail.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Sorry, Sammy. Not today. Gotta go make some money. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sammy looks disappointed. Larry pets him and kisses him on the nose.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. We’ll go driving on the weekend. You can stick your head out the window and drool down the side of the car and everything. How’s that? Sammy licks Larry’s face.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (baby~talk) Yes, and I love you too. INT.. LARRY’S STATION WAGON DAY 9 Elien is putting on her make-up as Larry drives. They pull up to a stop sign. The engine RUMBLES, BACKFIRE then STALLS. Larry sits a moment, calmly.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: This car’s a piece of shit, Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I know but if you shift into neutral just as you’re about to stop and keep your foot on the gas, it won’t stall.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: And when the brakes go, I suppose we'll just drag our feet out the doors.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I don’t think that would work very well, Larry. Larry starts the car and pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen looks out the window as they drive by a boarded-up miniature golf course called "The Golf of Mexico" with a large, battered sombrero over the sign. Anew sign is bein hoisted that READS: "Future Home of Mr. Croissant". (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I don’t believe it. Look. They‘re going to tear down "The Golf of Mexico." That’s where we went on our first date. Remember?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Wasn’t that our second date?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: No, it was our first date. I remember specifically because the sombrero kept slipping down over your eyes and you tripped over the grinning bandito and split your pants. '

dialogues.speaker: LARRY Y
dialogues.text: I thought our first date was at Mr. Pizza. I remember because you ordered anchovies and were belching all night. 2

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (laughs) That was our third date. And I just burped a few times.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Then where was our second date?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (thinks) I can’t remember. I guess nothing exciting happened that time. They HEAR the WAIL OF A SIREN and look back to SEE: A HELMETED MOTORCYCLE COP pointing him toward the curb.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (groaning) Is that for me? It can’t be for speeding. Not in this piece of shit! Larry pulls over. The engine RUMBLES, BACKFIRES then STAL

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Just be nice and he’1l be nice back.  121 -15- EXT. ROADSIDE DAY il Larry rolls down his window, smiling pleasantly. The Motorcycle Cop, early 50s, peers in. (THIS IS THE FIR

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Morning, Officer. Is something wrong? coP Your vehicle is emitting dangerous levels of hydrocarbons, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: It is? Well, I’ll certainly get that fixed right away, officer. Thank you very much for pointing it out. cop I’m sorry, but I’1l have to issue : a citation. License and registration please. Larry reaches for his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (to Ellen) Nice didn’t work too well, did it? He hands the cop his license and registration. cop Thank you, Mr. uh, Burrows. The cop is about to go back to his motorcycle, then stops and turns back to Larry.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Burrows? Burrows? I know that name. There was a guy named Burrows who blew the highschool championship back in 1970. Was that you? Larry winces.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Uh, no. That was, uh...another guy named Burrows.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) He’s the one alright! Larry looks over at Ellen: Thanks a lot.  -16-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The station wagon pulls into the huge parking lot of “LIBERTY REPUBLIC SPORTING GOODS", a large, suburban~base manufacturing and distribution complex. The engine RUMBLE BACKFIRES, then STALLS. Larry and Ellen get out of the station wagon.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Are you still mad?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Why should I be mad? If you enjoy making a fool out of me in front of policemen, that’s perfectly fine with me.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Come on, sweeheart. I was just é teasing. You take that baseball” stuff way too seriously.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about it. It’s already forgotten. @ He starts walking away.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Don’t I get a kiss? He comes back. They kiss lightly.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: See you after work.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Oh, I forgot. I’m gonna be late tonight. There’s a union meeting.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Again?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: We're electing a Strike Committee and they want me to be the chairman. Somebody’s gotta stop those management bastards from laying everybody off. She heads toward the factory building.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: ' But what about dinner? ° (CONTINUED)  12 13 ~17-

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (calling back) There’s Lean Cuisines in the freezer and Coors in the fridge. Have a good one, sweetheart. Larry watches Ellen disappear into the factory.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (to himself) But today’s my birthday... He turns towards the office building.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I guess she forgot. INT. LARRY’S CUBICLE DAY 13 cU: Larry is doodling on a pad: a drawing of a stick man drowning in an ocean and screaming for help as a big shar fin comes up beside him. “VOICE How they hangin’, Lare? Larry looks up to SEE The Company President, JACKIE EARLE BUMPUS, 40, a large back-slapping sort-of guy. Larry crumples up the drawing and leaps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Bumpus. They‘re hanging just fine, sir. _

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE EARLE
dialogues.text: Good. And lay off the Mr. Bumpus crap, Lare. We’re all on the same team here. When I played for the Bears they called me Cementhead. But you can call me Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Jackie, sir. As Jackie Earle talks, behind him Larry SEES the face of CLIP METZLER, the "nerdy benchwarmer" from the flashback, rise up behind the separator wearing the slinky eyeglasse Larry has trouble trying not to laugh. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE EARLE
dialogues.text: I was just going over the quarterly reports, Lare. Damn good work. A real touchdown.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. Just doing my job. Clip continues goofing around behind Jackie trying to mak Larry laugh: .pantomiming walking down stairs, pretending to hang himself with his tie, mouthing Jackie’s words etc

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE EARLE
dialogues.text: An@ don’t think I don’t appreciate it. You know a quarterback’s only as good as his linemen. Hell, I’m just a big old dumb jock who got i lucky and married the boss’ . . daughter. It’s guys like you who _ make me look like a hotshot. . Clip is in the b.g. strutting around like a "hotshot". Larry can't resist and a laugh snorts out of his nose.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Sorry sir. I guess I’m coming down with a cold or something.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE EARLE
dialogues.text: Know what’s good for that, Lare? Eucalytpus extract and honey in two ounces of warm Napoleon Brandy with a tablespoon of rosehips and a dash of cayenne pepper. Then get into a hot bath for 15 minutes, and put a damp cloth soaked in lemon juice over your face. Got all that?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Got it, sir. Extract, honey and...al1 those other things... Jackie Earle stands up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE EARLE
dialogues.text: Atta boy. Well, keep up the good work, Lare, and good luck with the cold. I just stopped by to see how you’re doing. Jackie Earle turns and catches Clip in mid-goofy-face. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE EARLE
dialogues.text: Clipper! Hey, that’s a funny face, Clip looks terrified but Jackie Earle just slaps him on t back and heads down the hall laughing.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE EARLE
dialogues.text: Gotta teach that one to my kid. Clip enters the cubicle.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot, Clip. I’m trying to get a promotion and all you can do is goof around.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Will you relax, Mr. . Worried-about~every-~little-thing. Your suck-points are safe. Old Cementhead didn’t notice a thing. . foo many hits on the helmet if you ask me.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: oh, his heart’s in the right place.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Yeah, but we’re not sure where his brains are. Clip tosses a package on Larry’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Here. Happy 35th, buddy boy.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Why, thanks, Clip. I honestly didn’t think anyone remembered. He opens the package to find a slab of rubber vomit.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY -
dialogues.text: Wow. Artificial Puke. How'd you know what I wanted?

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: That’s not just any old barf, Lare. Take a closer look. Larry examines the vomit closely.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Don’t you recognize it?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Should I?

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Of course you should! That’s the stuff we used to throw into the girl’s locker room to scare ‘em so they’d all come running out in their underwear.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (brightening) This is it? The actual stuff!? But I thought Mr. Green confiscated it!

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: I broke into his office the next @ay and confiscated it back. 4

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (remembering) God, we had fun in those days, . didn’t we?

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Tons. Which is why I’m giving it to you for your birthday, because I knew what a sentimental fool you are. Clip moves slyly closer to Larry.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: And because...you make me sick! Clip grabs Larry around the head and tries to kiss him.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Now where’s my thank-you kiss?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Hey! Knock it off! Larry struggles to get out of Clip’s headlock.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: C'mon, Lare! One little kiss!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Get away from me, ya homo!

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE
dialogues.text: (off-camera) You two look like you're having fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: fhey stop, locked in their embarrassing embrace, and look up to SEE: the gorgeous CINDY JO BUMPUS, 33, smiling. Larry and Clip straighten up.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Hi, Cindy. How are you? Boy is this ever a coincidence! Jackie Earle was just in here. You know, your husband? Yeah, he sure looks good... Cindy Jo is enjoying Larry's awkwardness.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: How’ve you been? Boy, Jackie seemed fine...Clip and I are pretty good. Busy, though. Yeah, workin’ all the i time...So how’ve you been anyway? .

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: I’m fine, Larry. And thank you for . asking...three times.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (nervous laughter) Well, I just wanted to make absolutely sure...

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: Do you know if Jackie went back to his office?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. I’m sure he did. Lots of work to do, ya know. Touchdowns and all that stuff.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: (smiling) Nice seeing you, Larry. Bye, Clip. Cindy Jo smiles and glides away.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Always nice seeing you, Cindy. Larry and Clip lean out of the cubicle and watch her go.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Boy, do you have a way with women.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: @ She’s so beautiful. I shoulda moved in on her when I had the chance. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: When did you ever have the chance?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: In ninth grade. When I was coming out of the can one day, she was standing by the drinking fountains. And she smiled at me.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Yeah, so?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: So...she smiled at me. You know, smiled!

dialogues.speaker: CLIP 4
dialogues.text: You mean as in...exposed her-teeth? / LARRY . Exactly!

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Geez! I’m surprised you didn’t throw one into her right there on the spot! Larry watches wistfully as Cindy Jo stops and talks with SOMEONE down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (sighs) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry and Clip are moving down the line in the CROWDED cafeteria. Clip is loading his tray with food.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You ever have any regrets, Clip? You know, about the way your life turned out? About the choices you made?

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Nah. I figure I didn’t make ali that many choices. My policy is to do nothing and see what happens. And you know what? Things always seem to’ turn out fine!  -23- r 15 INT. CAFETERIA DAY - ELSEWHERE 15 Larry and Clip sit down at a long table. Clip begins eati as he speaks animatedly.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: You know what your problem is? Nothing’s ever good enough for you. And the problem with that is you’re never satisfied. And the problem with that is you’re never happy. And the problem with that is no one wants to go bowling with ya on Saturday night because you’re depressed all the time. And that’s a real problem. Right?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: It’s not that I’m depressed. I just wish things could be different once in awhile.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: You gotta learn to accept things as they are. You’ll get more bowling outa life that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I feel like there’s nothing going on in my life. Like I’m half-dead or something. cLIP You got it made if you ask me. You got a wonderful home,-a wonderful wife, a good job and the best friend money can buy. What else do ya want?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: A little excitement would be nice. A lunch tray CLATTERS on the table. Ellen sits down angri She is wearing a hair-cover and there is a dust shadow around her eyes where a pair of goggles were.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I am so mad I could scream!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What’s wrong, sweetheart? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Maddie and Heather just got laid off "due to slow sales” or some bullshit like that! And we’re already working double shifts just to keep up! Can’t you do anything about this, Larry? It makes me sick the way this company’s been treating us.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well...f dunno...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Larry, please...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, I’11 see what I can do. b INT. NILES PENDER’S OFFICE DAY 16 (cU) A walnut is broken open by a nutcracker with a LOUD SNAP. CAMERA FOLLOWS as a piece of the walnut is brought up to the mouth of NILES PENDER, 37. He begins to pace around the office speaking in very gentle and measured to as he eats the walnut.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Fenwick. State the problem, please.

dialogues.speaker: FENWICK
dialogues.text: Low profits. FOUR MANAGEMENT~TYPES are ranged on chairs around the office, The epicene LEWIS FLICK is standing by the door. Larry and Clip are seated on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: And the solution? Graham?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Higher productivity.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: What could be more simple? In order to make more money, we have to make more product, but not pay more ta make it. It’s a beautiful concept. Don’t you think so, Bennett?

dialogues.speaker: BENNETT
dialogues.text: Beautiful, sir. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Indee@d it is. Which is why, starting tomorrow all production quotas will be increased by 15%. And those who fail to meet that goal...well, let’s just say our company and their company shall...part company. Suddenly, Larry clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Is that a comment I hear, Burrows, or merely phlegm rising in your throat?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Just a thought here, Niles. But don’t you think it’s a little unfair ‘ to impose higher production quotas, considering we already have an inventory surplus?

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Really? And on what are you basing this so-called “surplus"?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: On the fact that I counted every single crate in the warehouse 10 days ago.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Hmmm. Then I would say we have a problem with our mutual perceptions of reality, for my own calculations show a considerable shortfall. The door opens. It’s Jackie Earle and LEO HANSEN, 63, Cin Jo’s father and the Chairman of The Board.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Sorry to barge in, Niles. Do Jackie and I need to be here for anything? Niles’ face breaks into the most obsequious smile.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Not at all, sir. Just boring production details. I can handle it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They leave. -26~

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Then we’re off to the golf course. (slapping Jackie Earle on the back) My son-in-law’s going to show me how to get rid of my slice.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Wonderful, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Oh, by the by, what time’s the Board meeting tonight?

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Seven-thirty. LEO . Won't be a long one I hope. We have a 9 o'clock dinner reservation...

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: You’ll be there in plenty of time, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Excellent. Goodbye then.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE EARLE
dialogues.text: Touchdowns everyone. Niles instantly drops his phoney smile.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Amazing. (to Larry) © Alright, Burrows, since we seem to have a disagreement on the inventory, I suggest you check it all over again.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: But that’ll take three or four days.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t see a problem with that. Lewis, do you see a problem with that?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: I don’t see a problem with that, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Do you see a problem with that, Burrows? Larry doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Well? Do you, Burrows? Larry opens his mouth to speak. Then thinks better of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry is in the warehouse, going through the inventory check. He is mumbling angrily, saying what he wished he could have in the previous scene. LARRY e Yeah, I see a problem, you dick. What are you going to do about it, huh? Huh?! You prissy little wimp! As he looks down at the clipboard, the two forks of a4 forklift CROSS FRAME in front of him. He looks up to SEE: A VERY PRETTY GIRL, JEWEL JAGGER, mid 20s, on a forklift, spearing a crate off one of the shelves next to him.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Would you mind stepping back? You wouldn’t want me to fork you to death, would you? The girl looks at him coquettishly. Larry laughs nervousl

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No, we couldn’t have that...I mean, after all, we’ve only just met...

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: ~ (very suggestively) Since when does that matter? Jewel smiles provocatively, then wheels away. Larry watch her go, stunned,

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: (off-camera) Va~va-va-voom! Larry turns to SEE his father, HARRY, a balding man in hi mid-50s standing where the crate was. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ~28- @ 17 CONTINUED: a7

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Not bad, huh?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Incredible. You know, sometimes I get the distinct feeling I’m missing out on something. They watch Jewel wheel down the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: What she’s got, and she’s got plenty, you don’t need.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You sure? 4 HARRY v Not absolutely. But if I ever tried to find out...your mother’d kill . me. Larry puts his arm around Harry’s shoulder and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: @ You’re the dad every kid dreams of.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Don’t be a wiseguy. Listen, Petey Fleckman just got canned. That‘s three guys since yesterday. Somethin’ stinks around here, kiddo, and I don’t mean the meatloaf special in the cafeteria.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah I heard...

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, lookit this here. Harry grabs Larry and points between a pile of crates. They SEE Niles Pender leading SIX JAPANESE BUSINESS MEN through the warehouse.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: That’s the same bunch he had down here last week. Looks like the same bunch anyway, who can tell?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: @ Who are they? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Who knows? Pender tried passing ’em off as some championship baseball team from Osaka. But I talked to one of them and he thinks Mickey Mantle is something over a mouse’s fireplace! Listen, check around will ya?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Okay, pop, I’1l see what I can find out.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: You're aces, kid. INT. OFFICE AREA DAY . » 18 LARRY’S POV: Niles’ secretary, GLADYS, 30, sitting in her cubicle in front of his office, talking on the phone. ,

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Mr. Pender won’t be back until 3 o’clock...Yes, thank you. Larry is standing next to the water cooler on the far sid of the office floor, taking a slow drink as he watches he Gladys hangs up. She takes her purse out of her desk draw gets up, and leaves the cubicle. Still holding the paper cup, Larry starts across toward Niles’ office. Larry is nervous; eyes fixed on the office door. We can H his heart THUMPING LOUDLY. He’s coming closer and closer to Niles’ door. His heart is THUMPING FASTER. Suddenly th door opens and Lewis Flick steps out. Larry quickly turns and veers off down the corridor. He stops in front of another water cooler and pours himself a drink, trying to be nonchalant. Lewis walks past, eyeing him suspiciously. Larry smiles casually. He upends the cup of water, then steals a glances at Lewis, who steps into another office down the corridor. Larry sags against the water cooler and takes a deep brea then he turns toward Niles’ office again.  19 20 -30- INT. NILES PENDER’S OFFICE DAY 19 There is a KNOCK on the door. A moment later, Larry peers into the office. It’s empty. ~ He crosses quickly to Niles’ desk. He checks one drawer: office supplies. He checks another: some papers. He paws through them. He checks a third drawer: it’s locked. He takes a letter opener off the desk and slides it into the lock. He twists the opener back and forth. It breaks.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: shit. He pulls the handle hard and the drawer pulls out of the desk. It drops on the floor, spilling papers. ‘

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Shit. Larry bends down quickly and starts gathering up the pape He picks one up and reads it over, frowning. CLOSE ON THE PAPER: It READS "Memo: Nakamura Industries Osaka. Re: Leveraged Buy-out via Metaspo:

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Leveraged buy-out? What the hell is Metasport? Suddenly, the DOOR OPENS. He crouches behind the desk.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (mouthing) Shit. FOOTSTEPS approach. Larry winces, waiting for the axe to fall. Shoes stop in front of him. He looks up, sheepishly TO SEE Niles, smiling down at him wickedly.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Lose something, Burrows?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (wincing) Something tells me I have. INT. LARRY’S CUBICLE DAY 20 Larry is cleaning out his desk. Clip is pacing, angrily. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: We shoulda killed that sonuvabitch back in the fourth grade when they wouldn’t have sent us to jail for it.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Forget it, Clip. I/11 just get another job somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: I’ll bet that dipshit’s been just waiting for an excuse to do this! Clip’s control breaks and he moves to leave the cubicle.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Well, I’ve had it! I’m gonna go . punch his lights out! LARRY . (stopping him} I appreciate the gesture, Clip. But if you get fired too, who’m I gonna borrow money from?

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Well, okay then. But I’m gonna get that slimeball some day.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, we‘’ll both get him some day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: A sign reading "STEDMAN FIELD". The same ballpa where Larry lost the championship game. We can HEAR the ECHOING CRACK OF BASEBALLS BEING HIT. CRANE DOWN TO FIND: Larry’s car parked in front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry is at home~plate with a bucket of balls and a bat. He’s a good hitter and each hit purges some anger.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (as he hits) Son of a bitch! (hits another) Goddam son of a bitch! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Larry turns to SEE a SECURITY GUARD, early 50s, approachi 32

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: (from the seats) Hey! What do you think you’re doing? You can’t do that! The park’s closed! (THE SECOND INCARNATION OF MR. DESTINY.)

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: You're going to have to leave.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, I’m leaving. Larry picks up the bat and the bucket of balls. GUARD . What’s the big idea anyway, a grown-up like yourself? Don’tcha have a job you should be at?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I‘m on vacation! Alright?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Say, hold on a minute. I know you. Aren't you that Burrows kid? From the all-state championship, 19707

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Gee-zuz pop, that was 20 years ago. Haven‘t ya got anything better to remember?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: I knew it was you,

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Thanks for making my day, pop. I really appreciate it. Larry walks towards the exit, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: (calling after him) So how come ya didn’t hit it?! My grandmother coulda hit that pitch! 22  23 24 ~33-

dialogues.speaker: EXT, STREET DUSK 23
dialogues.text: Larry's car stops at an intersection. The engine RUMBLES, BACKFIRES AND STALLS. He tries to start it again and agai but the engine won’t turn over this time.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (calmly) This can’t be happening. He sits still for a moment, then explodes in a GARBLED RA twisting and turning and beating the steering wheel. Then just as quickly becomes composed again.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: That’s better. He climbs out, opens the hood and peers in. ‘ LARRY . What am I looking at this for? I don’t know how it works. Larry slams the hood down. He looks around. The streets a deserted, the buildings dark. He looks up to the heavens and SIGHS. He closes his eyes and shakes his head in resignation.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I give up. When he opens his eyes, he SEES a PINK GLOW REFLECTED in the windshield glass. He locks back and SEES: A PINK NEON SIGN above a tavern at the end of a cul~de-sa that READS "End Of The Road Bar".

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Thank God. He starts walking towards the bar. INT. “END OF THE ROAD" BAR EVENING 24 Larry enters. The place is empty except for a BARTENDER i his early 50s, with a perpetual "Cheshire cat" grin and a gleam in his eye. (THE THIRD INCARNATION OF MR. DESTINY.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Evening.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Pay phone? The bartender points to a pay phone behind the door. (CON'TINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Larry goes over to the phone, drops in quarter and dials.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (wearily) Yeah, hi. I’m gonna need a tow... Over near the bar, the Bartender punches a selection into the jukebox, then goes back behind the bar. An instrument version of "Someone to Watch Over Me" BEGINS TO PLAY. He begins meticulously wiping glasses and stacking them o the counter. Always with a knowing grin on his face. Larry hangs up and comes over to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Car trouble, huh? 5

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Tow truck’ll be here in twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: can I get you something while you wait?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I could sure use it.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: A light beer, no glass.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah. How’d you know?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Just a guess. The bartender opens the beer.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Don’t I know you from somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You seem a little familiar to me too.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Name’s Mike. (thinking) I know. Larry Burrows, right? The Kid who lost the... Larry’s head falis to the counter with a DULL THUD. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Gee-zuz Henry Christ! Was everybody in the world at that game?!

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Sorry. If I’d known it was a sore spot, I’d never’ve brought it up.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Forget it. I’m getting used to it. This whole day’s been a nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Care to talk about it?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well, it’s alot of things. First 4 of all it’s my 35th birthday. and everyone forgot...well, almost everyone. I got vomit from Clip.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Well, happy birthday.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Thanks. I’m 35 years old and my life is shit.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Come now, it can’t be that bad.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: It’s not that it’s bad, it’s just that it’s ordinary. Everything’s the same, you know? I go bowling, I make model cars, I fall asleep in front of the TV every night. Tuesdays, we have chicken; Fridays, we go to Jack-In-The-Box. There’s just no excitement, no extremes, no fun.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Not everybody can lead a glamorous life, Larry.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, but why couldn’t I be one of guys who does? I got brains, I got talent. I’m as good as most people. Larry finishes the beer and shakes his head. e (CONTINUED)  24

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mike sets a Larry takes -36-

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: If only I’d hit that goddam ball. My life would’ve turned out a whole helluva lot better.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Some people believe things are the way they are for a reason.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well the reason eludes me. (holds up the bottle) Lemme have another, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Listen, I’ve got just the thing for a sober cynic like yourself. A 4 little something of my own design. I call it "The Spiilt Milk".

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: The Spilt Milk? MIKE . The one drink there’s no use crying over.

dialogues.speaker: . LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh that’s very clever, Mike. glass of milky white liquid in front of Larry.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: It does the job. Try it. a sip.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: It’s bitter. {takes a sip) No, wait, it’s sweet. It’s sorta bitter and sweet. It’s not bad!

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: So tell me more about your life ..+.do you have people who love you?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure, I guess I do.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Some people can’t even say they have that much. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: And you really think your life would have been better if you’d hit that ball?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: A lot better. Larry takes another sip of his Spilt Milk.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I swung too late, that’s all. (thinking) If I’d just started a half-second ‘ sooner...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BASEBALL PARK DAY, (1970)
dialogues.text: Larry is at the plate, set to swing. Haskins winds up, and throws. SLOW MOTION. The ball comes right down the middle, closer and closer and closer. Larry swings with all his might. KAPOW! He hits it deep to center field. Going, going, GON Over the fence. A towering homerun. The Crowd is on its feet, CHEERING. Larry rounds the bases to A THUNDEROUS OVATION as the Cro streams onto the field. As he touches home, his TEAMMATES hoist him on their shoulders and carry an ecstatic Larry around triumphantly. .

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT. “END OF THE ROAD" BAR EVENING 26

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (smiling) Yeah, half-a~second sconer and I woulda been King. A lousy half-a~second. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Larry drains the glass. He tosses some money on the bar.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well...I think I/11 go outside and wait for the tow truck. Thanks for the sympathetic ear, Mike.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Anytime, Larry. That’s what I/m here for. Larry exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry walks back to where his car was, but it’s gone. He looks around, anxiously. Then he GROANS.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Great! They towed it already! Larry turns to walk back to the bar and SEES that the PIN

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Terrific! Didn’t take him long to close. With a heavy SIGH, he starts walking.

dialogues.speaker: . LARRY
dialogues.text: This’s been a perfect day. Just perfect. EXT. LARRY’S HOUSE - DRIVEWAY NIGHT 28 A tired Larry trudges up to his house. He takes a few ste onto the driveway and stops. :

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: It’s paved! Well how about that? It’s paved! Guzelman came through! He stomps on the asphalt to make sure it’s real. Then he continues up to the house. EXT. LARRY’S HOUSE - DOORWAY NIGHT 29 Larry puts the key in and turns. Nothing happens. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh, c/mon. Ell-en! Hey! Hon-ee, I’m home! Can y’open the door? He BANGS LOUDLY on the door. Suddenly, a Larry jumps

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: c’mon, will ya? My key doesn’t work! HUGE BLACK GUY, 30, flings the door open.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doin’, bangin’ on my door like that!? back, apprehensive. LARRY o Hey! Who are you? What’s going on? What’ve you done with my wife?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: What’re you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Okay. Listen, man. Take whatever you want and leave. But don’t hurt anyone, and I won’t call the cops, okay?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: Cops? Man, I am a cop. The black guy flashes a badge. Larry shows

dialogues.text: Now just what’s your problem?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I live here. What‘’re you doing in my house anyway? Is there something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: Your house! I think you better show me some ID, pal. Right now. his drivers license to the cop.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK GUY
dialogues.text: "Lawrence J. Burrows, 11653 Bonny Meadow Lane, Forest Hills." (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BLACK GUY 4
dialogues.text: Go home and sleep it off! . He HEARS the door SLAM behind hin.

dialogues.text: I thought I was home. Suddenly, a cab pulls up. Mike pokes his head out.

dialogues.text: Hi, Larry.

dialogues.text: Mike? What’re you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Thought you might need a lift right about now. And an explanation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike drives. Larry is in the back.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Well, it’s all very simple really. You know that little thing you didn’t like about your life...

dialogues.text: You mean the baseball game?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Well, it’s been changed.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Changed? What do you mean "changed"? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You hit the three-two pitch.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I hit it?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Right out of the park.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: And that’s why I don’t live in my house anymore?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Exactly. When that moment changed, everything else in your life changed along with it. 4 Larry eyes Mike suspiciously. Then he smiles knowingly.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: oh I get it, I get it. This is great! (chuckling) Tell me, what’re they paying you? Because whatever it is, Mike, it ain’t enough. You’re good. You've got just the right amount of sincerity in your voice and a nice twinkle in your eye like this is all for real. I love it! » MIKE What is who paying me, Larry?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Ellen and Clipster. They set this up, right? It’s some kind of birthday gag. Who’sa black guy? Another actor? He was great too.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Larry...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Never mind, I don’t wanna know. I’m just gonna play right along. So, uh, Mike...or whatever your name is, do you do this a lot, I mean change people’s lives and everything? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I‘ve been known to make a few adjustments now and again. Larry is killing himself with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I love this! He makes a few adjustments. So the cab driving is, what, like a part time thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab pulls to a stop in front of a huge mansion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry peers out at the mansion. .

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: This is it, huh? My new home?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: This is it.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well, listen, Mike, why don’t you wait here until I. get to the door? You wouldn’t want to miss the expression on my face, wouldja?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Not for the world.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I assume you’ve been taken care of. But here’s another five anyway. You were great. Larry hands Mike a tip and climbs out of the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry heads up the walkway toward the house. He SEES the mailbox that READS "Burrows".

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Gee-zuz, what a production! They musta spent a fortune on this? He arrives at the front door, turns and waves at Mike. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (calling out) I’m here...at the door to my new home. Mike waves back. Suddenly the door swings open. A BUTLER is standing there

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh, hi there. I’m Larry. But you probably already know that, right?

dialogues.speaker: BUTLER
dialogues.text: Of course, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Is my wife here? As if I didn’t know. BUTLER . Of course she is, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: e@ Larry enters, looking around. He makes a face: impress LARRY ‘ Not bad. I didn’t know you could rent places like this for parties. So what’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: BUTLER
dialogues.text: (confused) Why, it’s Boswell, sir!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Nice name. D’you pick it out yourself? Here’s a fin. You’re doing a@ great job. Larry hands him a § dollar bill as he continues across th foyer to the living room. Boswell looks at the 5 dollar bill, perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: BOSWELL
dialogues.text: (to himself) A fin? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Hey Boswell. Watch how surprised I’m gonna be. Get ready with an academy award. He throws out his arms, dramatically, and steps into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh, dar-ling! I am ho-ome! Cindy Jo Bumpus runs into his open arms. She kisses hin passionately. 4 CINDY Jo . Darling, you’re home. I was worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry’s eyes open wide. Suddenly, TWO ADORABLE CHILDREN, A BOY AND A GIRL, about 9, wrap their arms around his legs.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDREN
dialogues.text: Daddy! Daddy! Did you bring us something? What did you bring us?

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: Where have you been? Ludwig went to pick you up, but they said you’d already left. Larry stares at Cindy Jo, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Cindy? What are you doing here? Are you in on this too? Where’s Clip and Ellen?

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: Who are Clip and Ellen? What are you talking about sweetheart? In on what?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: My surprise birthday party. CINDY Jo The party isn’t for another two hours, dear. And you told me you didn’t want it to be a surprise because you hate surprises. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: His eyes widen as he SEES on the wall behind Cindy Jo: ZOOM IN: A portrait of Larry, Cindy Jo, and the kids!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Gee~zuz Henry Christ! He leaps back a step.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: Darling? What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Uh, uh...nothing’s wrong... He looks from the portrait to the real live family. LARRY ¢ Uh, uh...would you excuse me a moment please! He turns and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike is standing beside the cab, looking very nonchalant. Larry hurries up to him, his face full of astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You were telling the truth, weren’t you?! It’s all real!

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: All real. Larry falls against the side of the car in shock.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No, I’m not alright! This kind of thing doesn’t happen every day, ya know...I mean, one minute you got this, then you got...this! Larry looks up at the large mansion. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (proudly) It is rather remarkable, if I do say so, myself.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I don’t understand any of this. How could my life change this much just because I hit a.stinking baseball?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Well, you see, Larry, one’s destiny is a very complicated thing. Every single incident in a person’s life affects everything else that follows. One little change can spin you off in an entirely new 4 direction. You hit the ball, became a hero, married the prom queen, and so on, and so on, until you find yourself...exactly where you are! Larry looks askance at Mike. He reaches out and pokes him in the chest to see if he’s real. LARRY . What are you, an angel or something?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Not exactly.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Then what? MIKE . Have you ever been faced with a decision, and you weren’t sure what to do?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure, plenty of times.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: But then something inside you made you choose one direction over another? You couldn’t explain why, but you absolutely knew which way to go.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, so? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: So that’s me. I make the suggestions and you make the choices. That’s how Destiny works, Larry. Very subtly.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well if you don’t mind me saying so, this certainly hasn’t been very subtle so far.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Well...there’s an old Roman saying about that...and I should know because I’m the old Roman who said it. "The Fates lead him who will: him who won’t,...they drag." i Mike reaches out and puts a hand on Larry’s shoulder. MIKE . Welcome to your new life, Larry. I hope you like it. Mike smiles, then suddenly disappears. Larry looks around in shock, feeling the air where Mike was.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Hey wait a minute. What am I supposed to do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cindy Jo and the kids are waiting by the door, looking ve perplexed. Larry peeks in, smiling sheepishly.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Hi. It’s me again. Larry.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: Why did you run out of the house, sweetheart?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh...iI, uh, forgot to tip the cabbie.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: Cabbie? Why did you take a cab? Why didn’t you wait for Ludwig? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Ludwig? Oh, Ludwig! Good old Ludwig...well, I didn’t wait for Ludwig because...because...I can/t remember what he looks like... Cindy Jo looks at Larry askance. CINDY Jo You must be tired, darling. Why don’t you fix yourself a nice drink before dinner? Cook is preparing your favorite.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Great! I just love...my favorite. But then, of course, that’s why it’s 4 my favorite. Right? 6

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry stumbles half in a daze into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I have a cook. I have a favorite. He studies a family portrait on the piano.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I have a whole new family! Good lookin’ kids, too. Wonder what their names are? He looks around the magnificently decorated room. He runs a hand over the fabric of the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (impressed) Nice stuff! Probably Scotchguarded too. He stops in front of a very BIZARRE-LOOKING PIECE OF SCULPTURE. He frowns and leans forward, squinting. He til his head to the left, then to the right. Then he bends ov trying to make sense of it upside down.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What is this s’posed to be? Suddenly, he gets the feeling he’s being watched. And he looks between his legs TO SEE: Boswell, UPSIDE DOWN, standing behind hin. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Larry rights himself, quickly.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Hey, Boswell. Nice to see you again. Boy, I never get tired of looking at this plaster thing. It’s great, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: BOSWELL
dialogues.text: Indeed, sir. Boswell is holding a silver tray with a glass of amber liquid on it. He offers it to Larry.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What’s this? BOSWELL e Your evening drink, sir. Armagnac. 1953. Larry takes the glass and sniffs.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Whoa! I think I’1l pass on that, thanks. But you know what I could @ really use? A nice, cold brewsky.

dialogues.speaker: BOSWELL
dialogues.text: A brewsky, sir?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Light, if ya got it, no glass. He puts the glass on the tray and starts across the room. Boswell exits, muttering “Brewsky? Brewsky?".

dialogues.text: Larry is standing in a large private gym complete with Nautilus machines, treadmills, free weights, exercycles, etc. looking around in awe. GARAGE NIGHT 41 OVERHEAD FLORESCENT LIGHTS FLIP ON ONE AFTER ANOTHER to REVEAL a long line of spotless classic cars: Dusenberg, e Porsche Spyder, Bugatti, Rolls, Cord, etc. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Larry steps

dialogues.text: ~50- 41 back in shock.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY

dialogues.text: . LARRY c Ah, that hits the spot. Thanks, Boswell. Have one yourself if you ike.

Next to it, is a framed newspaper headline, which reads: “BURROWS 9TH INNING HOMER EDGES FILLMORE!" There is a pho of Larry being hoisted in the air by his team-mates. Larry smiles. He raises the beer bottle in a toast.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I always knew I had it in me. CLOSE ON: The photo as APPLAUSE BEGINS.

dialogues.text: The APPLAUSE CONTINUES. PULL BACK from the photo to FIND: 40 PEOPLE gathered arou Larry as he holds up a wheel of exotic cheese. Other unwrapped gifts are spread out in front of him.

dialogues.text: Wow! Hey, just what I wanted...a big hunk of cheese. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Really. Thank you. Thanks, Stilton. You too, Mr. Steuben, thanks for the terrific glass thing.

dialogues.speaker: GUEST
dialogues.text: Happy Birthday, LJ.

dialogues.speaker: GUEST
dialogues.text: Many more, LI.

dialogues.speaker: GUEST
dialogues.text: All the best. He moves through the crowd. Suddenly, a

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well, it depends on which one you go to. Safeway’s probably the cheapest. But A&P’s not bad either. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: What? Oh! Safeway! I get it! It’s a joke! Har! Har! That’s a good one!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, har, har...Excuse me, will ya...buddy-boy. Larry moves away. The Blustery Guy turns to a WOMAN standing next to him.

dialogues.speaker: BLUSTERY GUY
dialogues.text: Am I going nuts or did LJ Burrows just make a joke? s ‘ 45

dialogues.text: Larry is standing at the bar, pouring a drink.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Lo! He turns to see his now-toupeed father, Harry, coming tow him, A BEAUTIFUL YOUNG BRUNETTE, GINA, on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Dad! You‘’re here! (realizing) Well of course you’re here.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Many happy returns, kid! Swell shindig! Say helio to Gina. Gina, my kid.

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: Very nice to make your acquaintance.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: We made our acquaintance in Morocco at Club Med, if you know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (te Gina) Excuse us a moment, will you? Larry pulls Harry aside. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Are you crazy? Comin’ in here with that girl? What if mom finds out? She‘ll skin you alive.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Relax, we signed the papers a week ago, I'm free and clear now. So what d’ya thinka Gina? Hot stuff, huh?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Papers? What papers?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Divorce papers! ‘ LARRY e (shocked) You and Mom are divorced?!

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Of course we're divorced. Nothing lasts forever. You told me that yourself! ~

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I said that?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, and you were right.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: But where’s Mom?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: What do you mean, where’s Mom? She’s in New York. Happy as a clam with her lunches and charities and all the rest of that old biddy shit. Now listen, can you spot me ten grand? Gina’s killin’ me to take her to St. Bart’s. Okay? You’re aces, kid. Harry slaps Larry on the back and goes off with Gina. Larry is shocked. It’s the first suggestion that things m not be perfect in his new life. Cindy Jo comes by. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: Larry, don’t just stand here in the middle of the room. Mingle. Larry is still in shock.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: My parents are divorced.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: of course they are, dear. Everyone’s parents are divorced. Now go take care of your quests, i VOICE e Great party, Larry! Larry turns to see Mike wandering past, all dressed up an sipping champagne. | LARRY . Mike! What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Enjoying the champagne. Mike continues on.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I’m going to mingle. Larry leaves Cindy Jo and follows Mike.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: Larry catches up to Mike who is standing by the hors d’oeuvre table, eating canapes.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You didn’t tell me my parents were divorced.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: This caviar is quite good.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Is there anything else I should know about? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I mean is there anything else that’s going to come as a shock?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: All of it will to some degree.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: To what degree?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You’ll see. You have to take the bad with the good, Larry. LARRY . What do you mean the bad with the good? :

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You didn’t think everything would be perfect, did you?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well, I suppose not...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Then just take it all in stride and you'll be fine. This is your life, Larry. Learn to enjoy what you’ve got. Mike pats him on the back and walks away. Larry thinks a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess I should. Boswell steps up with a bottle of beer on a tray.

dialogues.speaker: BOSWELL
dialogues.text: A brewsky, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry and Cindy Jo wave goodbye at the door, as the last GUEST leaves.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Nice bunch. And they give terrific presents. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: You still have one more present coming. Cindy Jo turns to go back into the house, then looks back seductively at Larry. cINDY JO I‘’ll be upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry pours himself a tall glass of straight scotch.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Okay, Lare, you can do it, babe. You wanted this your whole life. Just don’t get too drunk. You know what happens when you get too drunk. He downs the scotch in one gulp.

dialogues.text: He approaches a door. He straightens himself out, suavely knocks and goes in. A moment later, the door opens. Larry steps into the hallway, looking around, trying to recover nonchalantly.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Nice closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a KNOCK. Larry enters. He looks around the lavis appointed room: Cindy Jo is not in evidence.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Cindy? Honey? Are you in here? Then the fantasy starts: SMOKE ROLLS OUT, MUSIC BEGINS, LIGHTS, and Cindy Jo makes her appearance: a vision of sexual excitement.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: Happy birthday, darling. Larry’s eyes widen.

dialogues.text: -58- e 51 INT. DRESSING ROOM MORNING $1 Larry enters whistling "Happy Days Are Here Again". He is wearing a pair of pin-stripe pants and a white shirt.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (buoyant) Good morning, Boswell. Sleep well...I didn’t, if you know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: BOSWELL
dialogues.text: Your jacket, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Isn‘’t this a little drab for such a happy guy? I feel like something in red. BOSWELL . But you always wear the blue pinstripe to board meetings, sir. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Board meetings? (realizing) Sonofabitch! of course! I’m married © @ to Cindy Jo! So I must be the president of Liberty Republic!

dialogues.speaker: BOSWELL
dialogues.text: Indeed, sir. For some time now.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Of course. I knew that. It’s just that I’m so happy about it, I like to remind myself every so often. How do I look?

dialogues.speaker: BOSWELL
dialogues.text: You look wonderful, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Good answer! Give yourself a raise, Boswell. Hundred bucks a week.

dialogues.speaker: BOSWELL
dialogues.text: Most generous, sir. Larry exits, smiling.  52 ~59~
