dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Morning, kids.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDREN
dialogues.text: Morning, Father. Larry picks up a croissant.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Hey, Pillsbury crescent rolis! Juanita places a bowl of capuccino in front of hin. He looks down at it, perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What’s this? Cream of Wheat?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Capuccino, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Right. I knew that. He dips a spoon in the capuccino. He takes a sip.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (eyes widen) Whoa! This’ll keep you awake for the rest of your life, huh? Larry laughs. The kids stare at him askance.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Nice stuff though. Must be Yuban- Should you kids be drinking this?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: We always do, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh. I guess it’s okay then. {changing subject) So what’s up with you two? Going out for baseball, son? Gonna be a cheerleader just like your Mom, sweetheart? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ~60~- e@ 52 CONTINUED: 52 The kids look at one another: what is he talking about? Boy You told me not to go out for baseball. You said I’d get too dirty and sweaty.

dialogues.speaker: YY
dialogues.text: I said that?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Yeah. So I went out for the Young Republican Club instead. Because you said that’s how you get to be President.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY 5
dialogues.text: Oh right. Of course. ’ (to the Girl) And what’d I tell you to do, . sweetheart?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Develop my legs. So I’m taking Ballet. And guess what? Miss Baxter ' has chosen me to be the lead dancer in the school’s preduction of Swan Lake.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: President of the United States and a Ballerina, huh? Sounds good. Cindy Jo sweeps in, looking radiant.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: Morn-ning! She pats the kids on the head and kisses Larry.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Want some of this stuff? It/11 really dilate your eyeballs.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: Just juice, please, Juanita. I’m in a mad rush. I have a 9 o’clock with Raoul for a body perm, and primal scream therapy at 11:00. I’m just afraid the therapy session will ruin my perm...Maybe I should have my hair done after the primal scream. What do you think, darling?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Larry looks at her, uncomprehending; then he shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: You're right. What difference does it make? I/’11 scream but I won‘t throw myself on the floor. Larry smiles and nods, pretending he understands what the hell she’s talking about.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: Well, I’m off. Bye all. As she leaves, Larry holds up the bowl of capuccino.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh Cindy, would you pick up a jar i of Folger’s Decaf at the 7-11? This tastes like it’s been on the burner all night! . The kids are still staring at him. He smile sheepishly.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Nice stuff, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A classic, mint-condition ‘34 Dusenberg goes fish-tailing around a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: a SIGN which READS: "LJ BURROWS - RESERVED. ALL

dialogues.speaker: OTHERS WILL BE TOWED
dialogues.text: The Dusenberg SCREECHES to a halt in front of it. Larry, in the driver’s seat, is beaming. Ludwig is hunched down in the seat, sheet-white.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (getting out) . I told you we could beat that train through the crossing.

dialogues.speaker: LUDWIG
dialogues.text: So you did, sir. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Give yourself a raise, Ludwig. Hundred bucks a week. You’re alright. He glances down at his parking space as he walks by.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: My own parking space! It’s about time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry walks through, full of energy, waving to EVERYONE.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY ,
dialogues.text: Hey, how ya doin’! Nice to see ya. How’s it goin’! He winks and smiles at A PAIR OF PRETTY, YOUNG SECRETARIE He passes THREE GUYS standing at a coffee maker.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Morning, fellas! How they hangin’? The Guys watch him continue down the hallway, still wavin and saying "Hello" and "Good Morning". 1sT GUY How they hangin’? What’s with him?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND GUY
dialogues.text: I don’t know, but it gives me the creeps.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD GUY
dialogues.text: He had that same look on his face the day he fired the entire accounting staff. INT. LARRY’S OFFICE DAY 56 Larry enters his lavish office, looking around in awe.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Awwwww-right! He sits in his swivel chair and spins around and around. The intercom BUZZES. He hits the switch. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: (over intercom) Mr. Pender and Mr. Flick are on their way up, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh, shit. Do they still work here?

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Nothing. Whadda they want? t

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: (over intercom) I really wouldn’t know, sir. ,

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well, tell ‘em I’m busy. Oh, say, could you find out if a Clip Metzler and an Ellen Burr...I mean Ripley, Ellen Ripley work here?

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: (over intercom) I know Mr. Metzler works in accounting, but I’1]1 have to check on Ellen Ripley.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Thank you. He gets up and walks around the office examining things. He sees a bottle of Johnnie Walker Black on the wet~bar.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Aw-right, Lare. The good stuff. He opens a door marked "Private" to reveal an apartment, very sumptuously and tastefully decorated.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What is this?! Larry enters the apartment. The office door opens and his secretary, Jewel Jagger (formerly the forklift operator), enters carrying a cup o coffee and a stack of messages. She looks around the office; Larry isn‘t there. Then she HEARS something from the apartment and peers in.  57 ~64~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry is sitting wide-eyed on a King~Size Bed watching a BANK OF NINE TELEVISIONS SETS all tuned to a different program. He’s constantly moving his head, trying to follo each show.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (to himself) Nothing like watching nine different shows. at once. He sees Jewel and gets off the bed.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh! Good morning! (beat) Hey, I know you. From the forklift. i She hands him his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks, but I take it with milk and sug... She SLAPS his face.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Then again, black’ll be fine. She pushes him back onto the bed and straddles hin.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Just where the hell were you last night? I waited until midnight! Then I went to bed. Alone!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well, I’m, uh, real sorry, uh, uh...

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: It’s Jewel! Have you forgotten my name already?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Right. Jewel. I knew that. She gets up and storms out into the office. He follows, confused and nervous.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Listen, I’m really, really sorry, Jewel, but I guess I couldn’t make it. I had this party...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jewel pours herself a scotch and throws it back.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: You guess you couldn’t make it!? Where were you? Out with this Ellen Ripley bitch?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: pid you find out if she works here? Jewel advances on Larry pushing him back to his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she doesn’t work here! And if she suddenly starts working here, you‘ll live to regret it! She stabs the letter opener into his desk blotter. LARRY » Listen, Jewel, what do you say we double your salary? She sneers at him, then turns to exit just as Niles and Lewis come in, all business, speaking very quickly.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: LJ! What d‘ya think of the plans for the New Jersey plant? I wanna call Bob and let him know one way or another.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: I think it’s a big mistake to set up in New Jersey, lJ. When Jewel slams the door behind her, Niles immediately becomes conspiratorial.

dialogues.speaker: NILES-
dialogues.text: We need to talk, LJ. Someplace private. How about the Country Club? Nakamura wants our answer by close of business, day after tomorrow or he forgets the whole deal. Are we on?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: For New Jersey?

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: No, for golf! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Sure. But what about Bob?

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Who cares about Bob? The door opens a crack and Leo Hansen peers in, meekly.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Excuse me, LJ? Am I disturbing you? Larry leaps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Mr. Hansen, sir! Come in, come in. Leo sees Larry charging across the office toward him ard cowers back out the door. Larry pulls him back into the office. »

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What can I do for you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: I just wanted to apologize for not attending your birthday party last night. My ulcer was acting up and...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Don’t mention it. You didn’t miss a thing. A bunch of real stiffs. I got cheese and a glass thing. Can you believe it?

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: We really should get going, LJ. We tee off in fifteen minutes.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh, okay. Well, hey, why don't you join us, Mr. Hansen? We're going golfing. I play golf, ya know. I could probably help you get rid of your slice.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Really? You want to play golf with me? He throws an arm over Leo’s shoulder and they stroll out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Sure. Or maybe you could help me get rid of my slice. Whatever that is. Niles and Lewis look at one another, perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GOLF COURSE DAY
dialogues.text: Larry is about to tee off. He plants his ball, sets, and swings. But he tops the ball and it dribbles a few feet down the freeway. He runs after it.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No fair! That was only a practice swing! 5 Niles and Lewis look at each other, askance. Larry grabs up the ball and runs back to the tee.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I get one more try. He plants the ball again, sets, and swings. The ball hook right and bounces into a sandtrap.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Shoot! I landed in the dirt pit! Can I go again?

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Well, sir, there are some others waiting to tee off... Larry looks back TO SEE TWO FOURSOMES waiting impatiently

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Okay. C’mon Leo! I/1l1 race ya! He and Leo get into their carts and head down the fairway Niles and Lewis watch them as they race away: Larry drive erratically, swerving all over the course.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: I don’t get it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: I do. He’s playing the boob in order to lull poor Leo into a false sense of security before selling the company out from under him. I only wish I’d thought of it. They look down the fairway and see Larry swerving along, clubs tumbling from his golf bag.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: It’s absolute genius.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: Larry, Leo, Niles and Lewis are walking back to the 4 clubhouse. Lewis is holding a towel to his forehead. LARRY . I’m real sorry about that, Lewis. Didn’t you hear me yelling "Duck! Duck!"?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: The usual word is "Fore", LJ.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Right. Fore. I knew that.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Perhaps we could talk about the Nakamura deal after lunch, LJ? In private? There are a few points... Lar: stops suddenly: he sees Mike on the practice green showing AN ATTRACTIVE YOUNG WOMAN how to putt.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure thing, Niles. Would you guys excuse me a sec? I just wanna practice my putting. He grabs a driver out of his bag and starts over.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: Mike is wearing an orange golf shirt, red cardigan and greenish-mustard slacks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -69— e 61 CONTINUED: 61

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: And don’t forget the follow-through. There’s no use playing if you don’t plan to follow through.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: Thanks for the advice, Mike. The Young Woman leaves as Larry comes over, excited.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Mike! What‘re you doing here? As they talk, Mike continues his putting.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I‘m the club pro. For a moment or two, anyway. Though I must say I’m not overly fond of the attire.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Listen, Mike, I can’t thank you enough for what’s happened.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I’m pretty sure the color of these pants is unknown to nature.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What you said was absolutely right! Ya gotta take the bad with the good. And in this case the good is great!

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Most people believe power is the essential element of the game. The hard drive off the tee. The long irons down the fairway...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I got tons of dough, my own company, ~ a gorgeous wife who can’t keep her hands off me...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: But it’s finesse that’s most important, Larry. The easy, lofting chip shot. The gentle stroke across the green... Mike strokes a 35-foot putt across the green. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (leaning close) I’ve even got a mistress. Me! A mistress! Can ya believe it? The ball goes right into the cup.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Not bad.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Not bad? It’s terrific!

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Larry. LARRY t Thank you, Mike. " Mike leans rakishly on his putter. ’

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (smiles) Just taking care of business. Then he disappears. POP! His putter stands alone, not falling. Larry looks around to see if anyone noticed; no one did. Then he grabs the putter and walks away nonchalantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunchtime. The cafeteria is.CROWDED. Larry walks quickly through, waving cheerfully. EMPLOYEES stare at him in amazement. Larry slaps A GUY on the back.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: How ya doin’! Larry grabs a tray and starts through the line. _ He looks down the line and SEES something. His eyes wid

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh my God! HIS POV: Ellen is standing at the cash register. She is smiling and laughing with the CASH PERSON. She is radiant more beautiful than ever. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Larry runs down the line, excited, bumping PEOPLE aside.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Ellen! Ellen! It’s me, Larry! Ellen turns to see Larry hurrying toward her. She backs away, startled. Overjoyed, he wraps her in a big hug.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I’m so glad to see you! I was wondering where you were! EVERYONE in line is watching. Ellen is in shock. He holds her out at arm’s length and looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Boy, do you ever look great! Did you lose weight or something? She breaks out of his grasp and straightens herself’ up.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: They told me you didn’t work here- There’s no record of an Ellen Ripley and I knew it wouldn’t be under Burrows.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Burrows? Why would it be under Burrows? My name is Robertson.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Robertson? What’re you doing with that name?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: It’s customary for a woman to take her husband’s name, Mr. Burrows. Now if you’ll excuse me. She turns and walks away coldly. Larry follows her.

dialogues.speaker: . LARRY
dialogues.text: You‘’re married? When did that happen?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Six years ago. But don’t worry, I wasn’t married on company time. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Gee-zuz! What’dja do, marry the first guy that came along?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: If you don’t mind, Mr. Burrows, I'd like to eat my lunch. She sits down at a table; Larry sits down beside her. It suddenly Ellen walks

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: So who is this Robertson guy anyway? What’s he look like? What’s he do for a living?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Just because I work for you doesn’t 4 mean you have a right to pry into my private life. dons on him how out of line he is.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well, yes, of course it doesn’t. I’m just, uh, concerned...as I am about all my employees, Miss, I mean Mrs. Robertson.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Concern for your employees has never been your strong suit, Mr. Burrows...now if you’ll excuse me, I’d rather eat by myself. away, leaving Larry at the table, perplexed. Mike sits down beside him dressed as a factory worker. He has a tray of food.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You really should do something about this meatloaf, Larry. It’s absolutely inedible.

dialogues.speaker: . LARRY
dialogues.text: What's with Ellen? Why’s she so mad at me?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: She’s the union shop steward. The union is upset over all the lay-offs, the increased workloads, the pay freezes...and I’m sure, the meatloaf. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: So? What’s that got to do with me?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You're the president of the company. Their mortal enemy.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: But I wouldn’t lay anybody off.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: But you did. And so...Ellen hates your guts.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Ellen hates my personal guts? MIKE e With a passion.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No. I don’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You’ll find a lot of people don’t like you, Larry. That’s the price you pay for power and wealth.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well, what am I gonna do? I can’t have her hating my guts all over the place. She’s my wife, for Chrissake! MIKE . Was your wife, I have to go now. This meatloaf is making me sick. Really, Larry, do something about the food in this place.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What am I going to do about Ellen?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Whatever you do will be fine. see you later. Mike disappears again.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (to himself) He‘s a big help. It suddenly occurs to him that Mike just disappeared. He looks around quickly to see if anyone noticed.  ~74~

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY DAY
dialogues.text: Larry is walking down a hallway, still confused and upset

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (mumbling) I’m not a bad guy. I’m a nice guy! He stops a YOUNG EMPLOYEE walking by.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Hey kid, I’m a nice guy, right? You like me, right?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: (terrified) Yes sir, I like you, sir. LARRY i Good. Give yourself a raise.» He continues down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (to himself) I knew I was a nice guy. Suddenly, from a doorway right in front of him, a stream of papers comes flying out into the hall. There is a CRY of anguish from the room. Then a HORRIBLE ELECTRONIC WHINE and a LOUD CRASH. Larry peers into the room to SEE:

dialogues.speaker: INT. XEROX ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: A MAN, his back to the door, is trying to catch the sheet of paper spewing from a huge Xerox machine.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Geez, I think ya busted it, pal. The Man turns: it’s Clip Metzler, looking panicked.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Clipper! It’s you! Clip’s eyes widen in terror.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Oh, my God, Mr. Burrows, sir... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Cut the "sir" crap, Clipper, it’s me, Lare! C/’mere, gimme a hug. God, I’ve missed you. He starts toward Clip with his arms wide.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Wait’1l I tell you what happened! Clip begins backing away.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: It was an accident, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I’m the President of Liberty Republic! Can you believe it? Larry keeps advancing; Clip backs around behind the Xerox machine. cLIP I’m aware of that, sir. And I want you to know that I’1ll pay for any damages...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Forget about that! Just come over here so I can kiss your head! Larry keeps advancing on him. Clip GASPS, darts around the other side of the machine an races out the door.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Clip! Come back here! What’s the matter with you?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry comes out of the Xerox room and calls after Clip wh is running as fast as he can down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Clipper! For Chrissake come back here, will ya! Larry takes a few more steps, then stops as “he SEES Clip disappear around a corner at the far end of the hall.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Clipper? It’s me, Larry.  -76~ e 66 INT. LIMOUSINE DAY 66 Larry is sitting in the back, looking out the window, dee in thought. Ludwig is driving.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something, Ludwig?

dialogues.speaker: LUDWIG
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Do you like me?

dialogues.speaker: LUDWIG
dialogues.text: Yes sir, I like you very much, sir. In the BACKGROUND, we HEAR a CAR HORN: HONKING. LARRY . Are you just saying that because I pay your salary? .

dialogues.speaker: LUDWIG
dialogues.text: No sir. I would say that even if you didn’t pay my salary. @ Larry nods, disbelieving. In the BACKGROUND, the HORN HONKING GETS LOUDER. Larry looks out the window again at a CAB DRIVER in the c next to him. HIS POV: The cab driver is shaking his fist at him.

dialogues.speaker: CAB DRIVER
dialogues.text: Why don’t you get outa the way! Make some room for the rest of us! The Cab Driver is Jackie Earle Bumpus, looking a lot less prosperous and happy. Larry brightens and rolls down the window.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Jackie! It’s me, Larry Burrows!

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE EARLE
dialogues.text: I don’t care who ya are, ya piece of rich shit! Ya think ya own the whole road or something? . The cab pulls ahead and cuts the limo off, forcing it t e stop sharply at the curb. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LUDWIG
dialogues.text: Are you alright, sir?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m fine. Larry looks out the window into an alleyway and SEES: A mangy dog rooting around in the garbage. Larry squints: it’s Sammy! Larry jumps out of the limo and starts down the alley.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Sammy! Sammy! Here boy! Here boy! Sammy SEES Larry approaching and GROWLS, bearing his teet

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Sammy! It’s me. Larry. . Sammy continues backing away and GROWLING.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Come on, boy. Let’s go for a ride in the car. You can stick your head out the window and everything. Sammy GROWLS VICIOUSLY, then turns and runs down the alle

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Sammy! His call ECHOES down the alley. INT. LARRY’S HOUSE ~~ DEN NIGHT : 67 Newspapers are spread on the floor. Larry, dressed in a tuxedo, is sitting cross-legged surrounded by the bits an pieces of a model car. He seems sad, lost in thought as h examines the door-piece of the model.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: (from behind) Larry! We’re going to be late! What on earth are you doing? He turns to SEE Cindy Jo, in an evening gown, his son in a tuxedo and his daughter in a frilly dress. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I don’t feel like seeing Opera tonight. I never cared that much for it to tell you the truth. All that hollering in Italian...I can never tell what they’re saying. Cindy Jo comes over to see what he’s doing.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: What‘s this?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: A Gull-wing Mercedes. Pretty, isn’t it? CINDY JO i Yes I know, dear. You have one in the garage. LARRY . That one’s too big. He looks at the half-finished model.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I kinda like ‘em smaller. CINDY JO . Are you alright? You’ve been acting very strange lately.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I’m fine. You guys go on without me. Have a good time. I need to finish this up. Cindy Jo sighs and exits with the kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry’s ‘54 Porsche Spyder pulls up across the street fro a small bungalow, nicely-kept, on a quiet street. Larry, still in his tux, looks out at the house a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Nice house. Better than the one we had. Suddenly, the front door opens. Ellen’s husband TOM ROBERTSON, 36, very good-looking, comes out. He starts do the sidewalk. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Larry ducks down in his seat. Suddenly, Robertson turns back toward bungalow.

dialogues.speaker: , TOM
dialogues.text: I just wanted to borrow some cutlery, Ellen. I have no cutlery. None. All I’m asking for is a couple of lousy knives and forks! Ellen comes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Why don’t you ask your girlfriend for a knife and fork! Or does the little bitch eat with her fingers! Robertson tries to take on a friendlier tone. TOM an Come on, honey, be reasonable. I made a mistake, and I’m very sorry for it. Now can’t we try to put all this behind us? Ellen slams the door with a resounding BANG. Robertson turns and starts down the sidewalk again. Larry realizes what’s going on and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: This is good. This is very good. Larry eases out of his car and sneaks across the street a Robertson gets into his Corvette and drives off. Larry approaches a side window of the bungalow and peers in. He SEES Ellen pacing angrily in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: That miserable rotten creep! Ellen picks up a framed photo of Robertson and throws it in the fireplace. Then she walks out of the room. Larry chuckles gleefully.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: That’s my girl. Suddenly, the huge face of a St. Bernard lunges out of nowhere at the glass, BARKING LOUDLY. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 68 -80- CONTINUED: (2)° 68 With a STARTLED CRY, Larry tumbles backward into the shrubbery. Ellen comes back in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: What’s the matter, Hercules? You want out? The dog keeps on BARKING.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Okay, come on. She pulls the dog from the window. The front door opens and the St. Bernard comes charging o SNARLING and BARKING. It races across the lawn and begins sniffing the trunk of a tree. PAN UP the trunk to find Larry sitting in the branches, looking down and breathing heavily.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (whispering) Go away. Get outa here. Scram. Suddenly, Mike appears beside Larry, startling him -

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Geezuz, don’t do that! I almost fell outa the tree.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: This is a very strange place to be spending the evening and you seem a touch overdressed.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Keep your voice down. Where in God’s name have you been anyway? Everything’s turned to shit! All my old friends hate my guts. Ellen, Clip, Jackie Earle, even Sammy. .--

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: But you have new friends now. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: They’re a bunch of jerks! I want my old friends back. They might’ve been a little weird, but at least they were real people. They wouldn’t give me cheese for ny birthday, I’11 tell you that much.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Well, as I told you, you have to take...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I know, I know...the bad with the good. You’re full of cute little sayings, aren‘’t you? I just want my old friends to like me. Is that : so much to ask?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You can’t have everything, Larry.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Again with the sayings.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Larry, you have to understand that people see you differently now. It goes with your new life.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: But how come I was such a nice guy in my old life and I became such a prick bastard in this one?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Even a nice guy can become unlikable given the right set of circumstances. Sometimes things just happen and you don’t really have a Choice in the matter.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No choice, huh? Well we'll see about that. I think it’s time to make Some changes around here. The St. Bernard starts BARKING at them again-

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Can’t you do anything about this?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Go away doggie. Beat it. Shoo. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The St. Bernard doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Didn’t work. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I’m starting to wonder about you.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I told you I only make suggestions. Taking them or not is up to the suggestee.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well, how do. you suggest we get out of this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MIKE ‘ The real question, Larry, is how do you get out of this. : Mike smiles and disappears.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I’m getting real tired of all this disappearing shit. WIDE: the tree, the St. Bernard still at the foot of it.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Shoo. Scat. Scram. Get outa here. Go rescue skiers in the Alps or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog is gone. The sun is up. Birds are CHIRPING. We HEAR SNORING. Then a sudden SNORT and Larry tumbles ou of tree and hits the ground with a DULL THUD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CROWD is gathered in the parking lot, staring up at the office tower. A FIGURE is standing on the edge the roof 10 stories up. Niles and Lewis are there with TWO SECURITY MEN. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Crowd parts as the Porsche pulls in. A dissheveled La gets out, his tuxedo soiled and askew. He tries to brush himself off and looks up TO SEE: THE MAN on the uppermost ledge of the building.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Some lunatic named, uh...what’s his name, Lewis?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Metzbaum, Metsfield, I don’t know...he’s in accounting.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Metzler? Clip Metzler?

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: He‘s threatening to jump.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well don’t just stand there, get something soft on the ground. Lewis, get some men to get 3 or 4 trampolines out of the warehouse.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: But LJ...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Just do it! Now! He might hurt himself, for God’s sake! Lewis jumps to it. Larry starts off toward the tower. Ellen is watching from the edge of the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clip is standing on the edge. He’s having trouble looking down. Larry comes out onto the reof and starts toward hin.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Be careful, Mr. Burrows. You know what happens to a guy when he falls onto concrete from 130 feet up? -Larry stops about 10 feet away. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Well, course I don’t know for sure myself. But it can’t be very pleasant.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Then why don’t we both get down from here, Clip, where it’s safe?

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: What for? My whole life has been one disaster after another. Nothing I do ever works, I’m a loser. And after what happened yesterday, I know you’re going to fire me. I’m just tired of failing, that’s all. LARRY “ I’m not going to fire you, Clip. In fact...I came up here to offer . you a new job. Executive Vice President! One twenty-five to start.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: (brightening) Really!? :

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: (realizing) Oh I get it. I know what you’re doing. You‘re just trying to talk me out of this. As soon as I’m back down on the ground, Boom! No job, and I’m off to the funny farm. Don’t kid me, Mr. Burrows. I may be a goof but I’m no dope.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I’m net kidding you, Clip. Nothing will happen. I give you my word.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Why should I take your word for anything? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Because we’re friends...I mean, we were friends. Remember? Back in the eighth grade? When we used to hang around together? And throw rubber vomit in the girl’s locker room so they'd run out in their underwear? Clip is staggered back a step. He teeters on the edge.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: You remember that?!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Of course I do. And remember when we saw "Bonnie and Clyde" 9 times, then squirted ketchup on ourselves , and ran around dying in slow motion all over the place. Clip smiles, remembering. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that was fun. Scared the crap outa my baby sister.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: And I remember how you used to always try to make me laugh when I felt rotten.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Gee, I didn’t think you even thought about all that stuff anymore.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I think about it all the time. A vulnerable Clip looks at Larry.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Cc’mon, Clip, lemme take you down. 72

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PARKING LOT DAY
dialogues.text: Clip and Larry come out of the tower, Niles and Lewis rush forward with the Security Men.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Hold him for the police! Larry steps in front of Clip. The Security Men stop. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Larry spies Ellen steps -86- 72

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Back off, Pender. No police.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Do you want us to throw him off the property?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I want you to get him a Mercedes. The Vice President of East Coast Sales can’t be seen in anything less.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Vice-President? LARRY i Read my lips, Pender. NILES . Yes, LJ, you’re the boss.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You’re damn right I am. Ellen in the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Now get the board together! I want a full meeting in ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Yes, LJ.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Miss Ripley! I mean...Mrs. Robertson... out of the Crowd.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Can you get your people together?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Good! Meet us in the board room in ten minutes. We’re going to put an end to this strike bullshit once and for all. Niles, Lewis, Ellen etc. stand looking at him a moment, amazed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well, move it, people!! Let’s go! They all scatter. Larry feels pretty good. He beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MANAGEMENT AND LABOR TEAMS sit across the long boardroom table from each other, ARGUING LOUDLY. Suddenly, the DOOR SLAMS. ALL turn to SEE Larry.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I’ve just finished reading the latest contract demands and they seem...very reasonable. A MURMUR of disbelief from ALL.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Reasonable? But, LJ...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: In fact I’m prepared to agree to all of them...on one condition... (peat) That Mrs. Robertson and I meet alone toa go over the final details... An UPROAR in the BACKGROUND. Ellen‘’s eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Perhaps tonight over dinner.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: LJ, I don’t think we should be so hasty...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Dinner? But I don’t see why we can’t do it...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: It would be strictly business, Mrs. Robertson. You want to bring this dispute to an end, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Well, yes...of course I do. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: There are a few things you seem to be forgetting, LJ!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I‘’ll pick you up at seven. How’s that?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Well, okay...I guess.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (smiles} Good. Then it’s a date. He extends his hand. ‘ Ellen hesitates a moment, then takes it and they shake on the deal. The UPROAR CONTINUES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry is at one end of the table, making some notes. The Other Board Members file out past Niles and Lewis. Wh the last has gone, Niles closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: How could you do that, LI?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Real easy once you get the hang of it, Niles.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Do you realize what a big union contract does to the Nakamura deal?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No I don’t. And just who the hell’s this Nakamura guy anyway and what’s his deal? Niles and Lewis appear puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Are you kidding, LJ? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 74 -39- CONTINUED: ” 74

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Do I look like I’m kidding?

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: What about this? Niles opens a file folder and hands Larry a memo. It READ Leveraged Buy-out via Metasport.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Metasport. Where’ve I seen this...ch, I remember now. This is the paper that was in your desk... He reads the memo quickly, eyes widening with shock. NILES ‘ As you can see, a union contract will drop the price by about 5 dollars a share. .

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You were going to sell this company to the Japanese! That’s what this is all about? (stops) Wait a minute. What’s my name doing down here at the bottom? 0h my God! Don’t tell me this was my idea!

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Of course it was, LJ. And it was my idea to buy up steck in a dummy corporation called Metasport so when the company sold, most of the profits would go to us.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: This is a deal worth 120 million dollars, LI!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (stunned) 120 million dollars!?

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Profit. To us. Larry thinks a moment. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well, that was then. This is now. The deal’s finished. We don’t sell to anybody and from here on, this company’s gonna be run on the square. He starts out, then stops at the door and turns back.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (smiling) Oh by the way, I hope you two have been keeping up your unemployment payments. Because this company and your company...are parting company. Have a nice day. He leaves. Lewis immediately starts pacing, wringing his hands,

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: oh, I knew it! I just knew it! He’s going to go to the authorities...

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Stop whining, you fat twerp! He’s not going to the authorities. LJ Burrows is too crooked for that. I know what he’s up to. He’s decided to take it all for himself. INT. LARRY’S OFFICE DAY 75 Larry is at his desk. He presses the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Could you step in here a moment, Jewel?

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Larry sits, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (to himself) She’s an adult, she’1l understand. He sees the letter opener on his desk and quickly slips i into a drawer. Jewel enters and comes over to the desk. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Yes, LU?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Jewel, honey, I realize I‘m probably the fulfillment of all your sexual desires, but I’m afraid our little affair has to end. Jewel stands looking at him impassionately.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Yes, LJ.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, but that’s the way I feel. We should never have let it happen. :

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Yes, LJ.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Under the circumstances, I think it might be better for both of us, if you found employment elsewhere. I’ll give you a glowing letter of recommendation, of course.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Yes, LJ.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (relieved) Well, I‘m glad you’re taking this so well.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: I guess some things just aren‘t meant to be, LJ.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: That’s the spirit. He comes around the desk and kisses her on the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I knew you’d understand. He goes out. Jewel calmly picks up a framed photo of Larry, looks at i then smashes it on the corner of the desk.  76 -92-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry is whistling as he gets ready for his date with Ell tying his tie in the mirror. Suddenly, Mike APPEARS in the mirror, staring back at him

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Geezuz! Don’t do that, Mike!

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Larry. It’s a brave man who takes command of his own destiny.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, thanks. I feel pretty good about it myself. MIKE . And you don’t feel guilty running. around with Ellen behind Cindy Jo’s 2 back?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Guilty? Why should I feel guilty? I just got here, remember? It’s not like I have a history with Cindy Jo or anything...I mean I hardly even know her...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Well, okay fine. Say, what do you think of this tie? I found a wonderful little shop...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Wait a sec, wait a sec. What do you mean..."well, okay fine"?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing really. It’s just that Cindy Jo’s been a loyal and loving wife for the last 10 years and the mother to a pair of adoring children, the fruit of your personal loins.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What are you getting at, Mike? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Your destiny has been changed, Larry..-by request I might add, and you have to respect the circumstances of your new life. They are of your own making, after all.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: If I made ‘em, I can unmake ‘em. Harry Burrows storms in and Mike FADES from the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Goddammit, kid! Lewis Flick just told me you torpedoed the Jap deal! LARRY ‘ You knew about that?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Don’t play dumb with me. You brought me in on this for a big slice. How d’ya expect me to keep a babe like Gina happy without a shitload of money?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: She’s not important, Dad. Neither is the money. I got it all worked out. Look at this. He hands him a telegram. Harry reads it.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: What? Your mother’s coming back? But she told me I was a ridiculous old lecher who should rot in hell. Larry puts his arm around Harry’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Everything’s gonna go back the way . it was, Dad. We’ll all be together and you can stop wearing that . ridiculous toupee. We’ll be a family again.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: You really think this is a good idea?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: It’s a great idea. You’ll see.  -94- @ 77 INT. BEDROOM NIGHT a7 Larry is putting the finishing touches on his outfit. Cindy Jo comes in, dressed in workout gear. Larry looks

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s just a business thing. Don’t wait up for me, it might go late.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: As late as last night? LARRY i Last night, sweetheart? : .

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: You didn’t come home at all last y night, Larry. at her a moment, trying to think up an excuse.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh, uh...0h, geez! Cindy! Didn’t my secretary call you? She was supposed to call you. It was incredible what happened. You wouldn't believe it if I told you.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: Try me.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well, I had to go out.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: For glue! For the model car I was . working on, remember? I ran out, so I figured I'd go to a 7-11. Which I dia.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: That wouldn’t take you more than fifteen minutes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Ordinarily, yes. But just as I was about to pay for the glue...these two guys came in. Big, mean guys with these big huge guns and started robbing the place! I couldn’t believe it! He stops and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Have you seen my car keys anywhere?

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY 5
dialogues.text: Oh...so then...after they tied up the Iranian guy, they took me hostage. We drove all the way to . the Illinois border, but then they let me go because I reminded them it’s a federal offence to take someone across a state line against their will.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you come home after that?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I was going to come home after that...but by then it was about seven o’clock and I remembered I had a breakfast meeting at eight. So I went right to it. I told my secretary to call you because I knew you'd be worried. Are you sure she- didn’t call? She was supposed to call you. Did you check for messages? I can’t believe it. she’s really incompetent. That’s it, I’m going to fire her. She’s history. . How do I look?

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: Larry, are you seeing another woman?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Who me? Of course not. Honest, honey, I was kidnapped at the 7~i1.  e = 79 -96~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry enters, letting out a deep sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Whew. That was close. He SEES Mike sitting in the '’54 Porsche Spyder.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh no, not again.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: James Dean used to drive one of these. I tried to talk him out of it but he wouldn’t listen. Great actor, though. Remember that drunk scene in "Giant"?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY ,
dialogues.text: Listen, Mike, I know what you’re trying to do, but I will not feel . guilty about this.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You can’t just run around mixing and matching the circumstances of your destiny in any way that suits your whims. There are other people involved.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Let me do it my way, okay? Mike eyes Larry a moment, then nods.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Fine. You make the choices, I onl. make the suggestions. Would you mind dropping me off downtown? I have to save an accountant from being erushed by a load of bricks. And off they go. S EXT. ELLEN’S HOUSE NIGHT 793 OFF-CAMERA, we HEAR a DOG BARKING. Ellen opens the front door. She looks fabulous. She smile as she SEES: Larry lying on his back on the sidewalk. Hercules, the St Bernard, has him pinned down with his front paws. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ellen comes over, still smiling, trying not to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mr. Burrows. Any trouble finding the place?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No, no. No trouble at ali. Hercules is still got Larry pinned to the ground. Ellen makes no move to call him off; she’s clearly enjoying thi

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: That’s good, that’s good.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Uh, these are for you. He holds up a bouquet of flowers. She takes them.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Oh, they’re lovely. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I’m afraid Hercules got dog drool all over then.

dialogues.speaker: . ELLEN
dialogues.text: How did you know his name was Hercules?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Uh, it’s right here on his tag. Which I’ve been staring at for the past five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Okay, Hercules. C’mere boy. Hercules climbs off and Larry gets to his feet. LARRY . I don’t think he likes me.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Well, he’s an exceptional judge of character. They start toward the Porsche.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: We're not starting off very well, are we? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Shit! Larry races away.. A second later, THE COPS peer out from behind their cover

dialogues.speaker: EWEL
dialogues.text: o Well, don’t just stand there. Go after the bastard and shoot him! EXT. ELLEN’S HOUSE NIGHT 106 The Spyder careens up onto the lawn in front of Ellen’s house. Larry races up to the door and pounds on it.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Elien! Ellen! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ~118- e@ 106 CONTINUED: 106 A moment later, Ellen opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Larry? What is it..?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Something’s happened. I’ve gotta get out of here and you’ve got to come with me.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Come with you where?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter. Jamaica, Mexico, Canada...As long as we’re together.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: But what’s happened? LARRY . I‘ll explain on the way. We’ve got to hurry! In the distance, we HEAR POLICE SIRENS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can start over again. Just like it was before. And I know you think it won’t work, but it will because we've already done it!

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Are you talking about that previous life thing again, Larry?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yes! Exactly! We’ll have Thanksgiving and Christmas and birthdays and breakfast and all that stuff, just like before. Don’t you see? We belong together. C’mon, rail help you pack. Ellen is hesitant, torn but gentle.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, Larry. That all sounds wonderful. It really does. It’s just that...after our dinner, I started thinking about a lot of things... about where I am in my e@ life...about what has real importance to me... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: That's my point! I’ve been thinking about what‘’s important too, and that’s why I think we should...

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Ellen? Ellen’s husband Tom comes up behind her.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What’s the matter? He puts a protective arm around an uncomfortable Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: TOM 4
dialogues.text: Hello...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Tom, this is my boss, Larry Burrows. Larry, this is my husband, Tom. Larry’s elation dissipates. He sizes up the situation in an instant: they’ve reconciled.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Hi Tom.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you Mr. Burrows... What’s going on, Ellen? Ellen looks down, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Uh...nothing. Nothing’s going on, Tom. I’m, uh, I have to leave town and I just stopped by to say so long. Well,..so long. He starts to walk back to his car. Just as he’s about to get in, Ellen comes up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Larry... Larry turns. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I was very wrong about you. I think you're a wonderful man...I wish it could have been different between us...but I guess it just wasn’t meant to be. I’m sorry. She touches his face gently, then turns and walks back to the house. Larry watches, his heart breaking, as his wife goes inside with another man and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: «--wasn’t meant to be...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET NIGHT
dialogues.text: Larry is driving down the street, lost in thought. Suddenly a Police Car, LIGHTS FLASHING, SIREN SCREAMING comes flying around the corner up ahead. Larry jams on the brakes, spins the Porsche around and ta off in the other direction. . The Police Car accelerates after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Porsche SCREECHES around a corner and accelerates dow the street like a bullet.

dialogues.speaker: INT, PORSCHE NIGHT 109
dialogues.text: Larry looks back and SEES no Police Car in sight. He turns back just as SOMETHING darts in front of the car

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Geezuz! Larry jams on the brakes. There is a THUD. 110

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET NIGHT
dialogues.text: The Porsche slews wildly across the street and slams into a light standard. A moment, then the door slowly opens. Larry climbs out, painfully. He SEES an object lying in the street. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He starts walking. Then breaks into a run when he realize

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: oh no! It’s his dog, Sammy, dead. Larry drops to his knees and cradles the dog in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh God! Not Sammy... SIRENS CAN BE HEARD a short distance away.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: It’s all my fault. I’m so stupid, so stupid... The Police Car careens into the street and starts toward him, SIREN SCREAMING. . Larry gently lays Sammy down, then sprints off down the street. The Police Car is gaining on hin. Larry darts down an alley. The Police Car pulls in after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Police Car is gaining on him. A COP leans out the window, pistol drawn, and FIRES A SHOT at Larry. Larry leaps onto a dumpster and vaults over a fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry lands with a CRASH in a pile of garbage. He climbs out, GROANING and brushing himself off. He looks up, startled to SEE: A BAG MAN, mid-30s, standing there, dressed in filthy clothes. Next to him is a shopping cart, full of junk.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Hiya doin’? Is there a way out of here? I‘m in a bit of a jam... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BAG MAN
dialogues.text: Hey, I know you. You’re...what’s his name...Burrows, right? The guy who hit the home run...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Gee-zuz pal, don’t remind me. The Man puts a filthy hand on Larry’s chest.

dialogues.speaker: BAG MAN
dialogues.text: Bet you don’t remember me, do ya?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No, sorry...should I?

dialogues.speaker: BAG MAN
dialogues.text: Haskins! Jerry Haskins! I’m the guy who threw the pitch! Remember now?! Thanks to you, I’ve spent the last : twenty years tryin’ to live that game down!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh, shit. Listen, if it makes you e feel any better, I didn’t get real good wood on it...

dialogues.speaker: BAG MAN
dialogues.text: .--always movin’ around...hopin’ they’d forget! But they never do.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: It was just a lucky swing...

dialogues.speaker: BAG MAN
dialogues.text: «..always hopin’ someday I’d run into you again! The sonofabitch who ruined my life! And now... Haskins takes out a club and holds it up, threateningly.

dialogues.speaker: BAG MAN
dialogues.text: ...Fate has brought us together.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (behind them) Hey! You! stop right there! They turn to see A COP coming over the fence. Larry shoves the Guy away and dashes across the yard. @ The Cop disappears down behind the fence again.  113 114 ~123-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry vaults over another fence and lands in another alle He runs down to the end, stumbling and then collapses against a wall, out of the breath. He looks both ways: nothing. He looks up to the heavens; then closes his eyes in total exhaustion.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I give up. A PINK GLOW magically comes up on his face. He opens his eyes and notices the GLOW. He moves away fro the wall and peers around the corner. TO A CELESTIAL SWELL OF MUSIC, he SEES the PINK NEON SIGN of "The End of the Road Bar". His eyes widen and he dashe toward it. . LARRY : . Oh my God! Mike! The Police Car SCREECHES around the corner, three blocks away and starts down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry bursts in.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Mike! Mike! Where are you? The place is empty.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Mike! This is no time to play games! I need you! But there’s no answer. POLICE SIRENS are getting CLOSER. Larry leaps over the bar and begins throwing ingredients into a glass. He shakes it all up, takes a guip. Then he spits the drink across the bar.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: That's disgusting! The POLICE SIRENS DIE OUT with a final WHINE. Larry frantically pours other ingredients into a glass. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We HEAR the SOUND of A VEHICLE PULLING UP OUTSIDE. REVOLVING FLASHING LIGHTS can be SEEN outside the window. Larry upends the glass, draining it. He GASPS and makes a face: it’s worse! WE HEAR a CAR DOOR OPEN AND CLOSE and FOOTSTEPS APPROACH.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Shit. Larry comes out from behind the bar with his hands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay! I’m coming out! Don’t shoot! I’m not armed! The door opens and A MAN DRESSED IN OVERALLS peers in: “TRUCK DRIVER . Somebody here call for a tow-truck? Behind the driver, we SEE a tow truck with the REVOLVING FLASHING LIGHTS.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Tow truck... Suddenly the realization rushes in on him. He whirls arou to see Mike standing behind the bar, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Don’t shoot? What’re you talking about? Nobody’s gonna shoot you, Larry. Larry explodes with joy.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I’m back! Son of a bitch! I’m back!

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Back from where? You’ve been here the whole time. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Sure I have! You old destiny-bender, you, (to the tow-truck driver) I love this guy! Isn’t he great? I just love him. (to Mike) I’m really back, aren’t I?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You've always been here, Larry.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (knowingly) Okay, Mike. Whatever you say. 5 Larry comes over and shakes Mike’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Thanks for everything. The good and the bad. You sure know how to make a point. He heads for the door and then turns back. °

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh, and listen, whatever you’ve got planned for the rest'of my life...it’s perfect! Mike smiles and raises a glass in a toast.

dialogues.speaker: _ MIKE
dialogues.text: Happy birthday, Larry. 115

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Tow Truck, pulling Larry’s car, stops in front of the Administration Building. Larry climbs out.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Where do I take the car?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: To the best shop in the city. Money’s no object! (proudly) . That’s my car, Goddamit! He runs toward the building entrance. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (to himself) I‘ll figure out how to pay for it later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Niles is in the middle of his report. Leo, Jackie Earle, Lewis, and OTHER BOARD MEMBERS are listening.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: As you can see, sales during the past two quarters have been declining and therefore I recommend we take Mr. Nakumura’s very generous buy-out offer of $35 a share.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Well, Niles, I must say, I find this ‘ very disturbing...what do you think, Jackie? JACKIE EARLE . Well, I don’t know what to think, Leo. This comes as quite a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Anybody want to know what I think? The Board turns to see Larry standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I think Niles is full of shit! This company is in perfect financial health.

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: You don’t work here anymore, Burrows! Get out!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Niles and Lewis have been buying up stock through a dummy corporation and doctoring the books to make it seem as if the company was failing so this board would be motivated to sell.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Niles, what’s he talking about? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Gibberish! Burrows is responsible for this entire fiasco! His mismanagement is solely to blame for the record loss we show in this quarter. Lewis, call security! Lewis reaches for a phone. Larry grabs it out of his hand Lewis tries to grab it back. Larry twists away and rips t cord out of the phone.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE EARLE
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, please! We’re all on the same team here. There’s no need for this kind of behavior!

dialogues.speaker: NILES
dialogues.text: Burrows is a thief and a liar! He’li say anything to regain his position with this company! I move that the x entire board vote to censure him and file criminal charges... LARRY . And I move you shut your face! And with that, Larry lands a fist right in Niles’ face. Niles drops backward in his chair, unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Sorry, Jackie. This guy’s never been part of the team. So I benched him.

dialogues.speaker: _ LEO
dialogues.text: Larry, is any of this true?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I suggest you check on a certain MetaSport Corporation af Delaware and pay particular attention to who its executive officers are. Yes, Lewis? Larry turns to Lewis, who is now sweating prefusely. He leans down and whispers.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I_ know everything, you snivelling piece of shit! Everyone else also turns to look at Lewis, who squirms fo a moment in his chair, and then bolts for the door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: That answer your question, Mr. Hansen? Leo gets up and comes around to Larry, beaming.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Larry, I don’t know what to say. I don’t know how to thank you. Is there anything I can do for you? Larry thinks a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, there is. EXT. STREET NIGHT m 117 A limousine races down a street. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry is driving. PAN OVER: Ludwig is sitting in the passenger seat, his face the color of chalk.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I teld you we could beat that train through the crossing.

dialogues.speaker: LUDWIG
dialogues.text: So you did, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limousine pulls into the subdivision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he drives up, Larry can hardly contain his excitement.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Look at this place! What a mess! It’s great, isn’t it? As he pulls up to his house, his smile fades. EXT. LARRY’S HOUSE NIGHT 121 The house is dark. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Damn! I forgot. Ellen’s at the strike meeting. Just when I want to see her more than anything else in life, she’s not here. He gets out of the limousine, his spirits dampened. INT. LARRY’S HOUSE NIGHT 122 Larry lets himself in. Suddenly, every LIGHT in the house COMES ON.

dialogues.speaker: VOICES
dialogues.text: Surprise! Larry jumps back a step, startled, as the crowd surges toward him, bearing gifts and huge smiles. :

dialogues.speaker: VARIOUS
dialogues.text: Happy Birthday, Larry! Many happy returns, Lare! Were ya surprised? Arf! Arf! . Everyone is there: Clip and Jewel, Harry, Sammy. And Elle looking radiant, much like she did in Act 2. Larry is so happy, he throws his arms wide and wades into them, hugging everyone. LARRY . Ellen! Sammy! I missed you guys so much! He scoops Ellen up in his arms and swings her around.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Since this morning?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: God, I’d forgotten how beautiful you are. He kisses her. Sammy leaps up, wanting to be hugged.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Sammy! Sammy! Larry lifts him up. Sammy licks him all over his face. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (baby-talk) Yes, and I love you too. (to the others) Geezuz, I never thought I’d see any of you again. Ever! You‘’re not going to believe what happened...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Clip told us. But don’t worry about it, we’ll manage okay.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh that...Who cares about that? I’1l get another job somewhere else. Clip approaches.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Happy birthday, buddy. >

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Clipper! Boy am I glad to see you. Larry gives Clip a big hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here’s your real present. I gave you the vomit just to throw off suspicion. It worked, didn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Like a charm. Larry opens the box to FIND a model of the Gull-wing Mercedes.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Do you like it?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I love it. I always wanted one of these. Thanks Clip.

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Come on, I want you to meet my date.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You have a date?!

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Yeah. Come on, let me introduce you. r Clip leads Larry over to his date: it’s Jewel! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: Larry, I want you to meet Jewel Jagger. She works down in the stock room.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Hi Jewel.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Happy Birthday, Larry.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’1l be back in a moment, sweetheart. . Larry and Clip move away. We HEAR the Larry opens

dialogues.speaker: CLIP
dialogues.text: (whispering to Larry) What do ya think? Is she a killer...or what?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (whispering) Definitely a killer. DOORBELL RING. the door. It’s Jackie Earle and Cindy Jo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie Earle! Cindy!

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE EARLE
dialogues.text: We don’t want to interrupt...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Nonsense. Come on in...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE EARLE
dialogues.text: I just stopped by to thank you again for what you did. You ran out of there so fast...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I hadda get home. It’s my birthday. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE EARLE
dialogues.text: Well, then I have a little present for you. The board voted unanimously to offer you Niles Pender’s job. Executive Vice president... Larry is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE EARLE
dialogues.text: Well? Are you interested?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Gee, I‘ll have to think about it. Okay, I thought about it...yes! They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE EARLE
dialogues.text: Wonderful. :

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: C’mon in. Have a drink! Jackie Earle goes on in. Clip slaps him on the back and steers him toward the bar.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY JO
dialogues.text: Gee, Larry, I wish I’d known it was your birthday, I would’ve gotten you something...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What do you get for a guy who has everything? She gives him a kiss on the cheek, then goes on in. DOORBELL RINGS AGAIN.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Larry, can you get that? It’s probably the guy with the pizzas. Larry opens the door. A GUY is standing on the front step holding a half-dozen pizza boxes.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: "Mr. Pizza". Sorry I’m late, the regular kid’s sick, I hadda deliver myself...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Jerry! Sonofabitch, Jerry Haskins! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: It’s the club-wielding bum from the alley; the pitcher wh struck Larry out. He leoks at Larry trying to place the face.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: It’s me! Larry Burrows!

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Larry Burrows? Gee-zuz, Larry. You remember me?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: The bastard who ruined my life!? Course I remember you! C’mon in, have a drink! It’s my birthday!

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Gee, can’t. I got a million deliveries. But, listen...here. _ (hands him the pizzas) : These are on me. Happy Birthday, Larry.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, Jerry...I can’t... -

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Den’t worry about it. I own the company. I/m "Mr. Pizza". He starts back down the steps then turns back.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Oh, Larry...I know I’m twenty years too late, but...sorry about the baligame. Larry smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Forget about it. He closes the door. CAMERA PULLS BACK To SHOW the exterior of the house, wind LIt. Then we HEAR "Louie Louie" BEGIN TO PLAY. SOUND ECHOES OUT. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: INT. STADIUM LOCKER ROOM DAY, (1970)
dialogues.text: Larry closes his locker, despondent. A teammate walks by, grumbling.

dialogues.speaker: TEAMMATE
dialogues.text: Way to go, dipshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry leaves the ball park, alone: a loser full of shame. Everyone’s gone, the stands are empty. It’s sunset. : As he walks across the field, he passes A MAN sitting in the stands. :

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: I saw the game, kid. Tough break. Larry turns: it’s Mike, smiling at him.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You said it Mister. I blew it good.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Don’t worry too much about it. It’s not the end of the world. You only think it is. Remember, you’ve got your whole life to look forward to. Trust me. Mike smiles. Larry nods doubtfully and starts to walk out of the park again, muttering as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Old fart, what the hell does he know? CREDITS ROLL to “Everybody Is A Star" by Sly and the Fami Stone.
